Intro

in this assignment, I had to create an object providing a rectangular area which can be moved and resized using the mouse.

Live Demo

here, you can see my program in action

VB.NET Code:

Public Class Form1
    Private x, y As Integer
    Private Rect As New Rectangle(50, 50, 50, 50)
    Dim isLeftClickDown As Boolean = False
    Dim isRightClickDown As Boolean = False

    Private Sub PictureBox1_MouseDown(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs) Handles PictureBox1.MouseDown
        If e.Button = Windows.Forms.MouseButtons.Left AndAlso Rect.Contains(e.Location) Then
            isLeftClickDown = True
            x = Rect.X - e.X
            y = Rect.Y - e.Y
        End If
        If e.Button = Windows.Forms.MouseButtons.Right AndAlso Rect.Contains(e.Location) Then
            isRightClickDown = True
            x = Rect.X - e.X
            y = Rect.Y - e.Y
        End If

    End Sub
    Private Sub PictureBox1_MouseUp(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs) Handles PictureBox1.MouseUp
        isLeftClickDown = False
        isRightClickDown = False
    End Sub
    Private Sub PictureBox1_MouseMove(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs) Handles PictureBox1.MouseMove
        If e.Button = Windows.Forms.MouseButtons.Left AndAlso Rect.Contains(e.Location) Then
            Rect.X = e.X + x
            Rect.Y = e.Y + y
            PictureBox1.Refresh()
        End If
        If isRightClickDown Then
            Rect.Size = New Size(Rect.X + e.X, Rect.Y + e.Y)
            PictureBox1.Refresh()
        End If

    End Sub

    Private Sub PictureBox1_Paint(ByVal sender As System.Object, ByVal e As System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs) Handles PictureBox1.Paint
        e.Graphics.DrawRectangle(Pens.Red, Rect)
    End Sub
End Class

Intro

in this assignment, I had to code a demonstrative program which computes the online arithmetic mean (if it’s a numeric variable) and an algo to compute the distribution for a discrete variable and for a continuous variable (can use values simulated with RANDOM object).

Live Demo

here, you can see my program in action

C# Code:

using System;
using System.Collections.Generic;
using System.ComponentModel;
using System.Data;
using System.Drawing;
using System.Linq;
using System.Text;
using System.Threading.Tasks;
using System.Windows.Forms;

namespace _2_A
{
    public partial class Form1 : Form
    {
        public Random R = new Random();

        public Form1()
        {
            InitializeComponent();
        }

        private void button1_Click(object sender, EventArgs e)
        {
            this.richTextBox1.Clear();

            int studentNumber = 101;
            int minHeight = 140;
            int maxHeight = 200;

            List<Student> listOfStudents = new List<Student>(studentNumber - 1);

            this.richTextBox1.AppendText("DATASET - Cryptography exam : Grades of students" + Environment.NewLine + Environment.NewLine);
            this.richTextBox1.AppendText("Total Count: " + (studentNumber - 1).ToString() + Environment.NewLine + Environment.NewLine);

            for (int i = 1; i < studentNumber; i++)
            {
                int randomNumber = R.Next(18, 31);

                decimal randomHeight = Math.Round((decimal)R.Next(minHeight, maxHeight), 2);

                this.richTextBox1.AppendText(("Student " + i.ToString() + ": ").PadRight(15) + randomNumber.ToString().PadRight(15) + randomHeight.ToString() + Environment.NewLine);

                Student s = new Student(randomNumber,randomHeight);

                listOfStudents.Add(s);
            }

            // OFFLINE ALGO

            decimal sum = 0;
            
            foreach (Student s in listOfStudents)
            {
                sum += s.gradeForCryptography;
            }

            decimal average = Math.Round(sum / (studentNumber - 1),2);

            // ONLINE ALGO

            double currentAvg = 0;
            int index = 0;

            foreach (Student s in listOfStudents)
            {
                index += 1;
                currentAvg = currentAvg + (s.gradeForCryptography - currentAvg) / index;
            }

            this.richTextBox1.AppendText("___________________________________" + Environment.NewLine);

            this.richTextBox1.AppendText("Arithmetic mean for Grades(naive formula): " + average.ToString("F") + Environment.NewLine);
            this.richTextBox1.AppendText("Arithmetic mean for Grades(online formula): " + currentAvg.ToString("F") + Environment.NewLine);

            Dictionary<int, Frequencies> frequencyDist = new Dictionary<int,Frequencies>();

            foreach (Student s in listOfStudents)
            {
                if (frequencyDist.ContainsKey(s.gradeForCryptography))
                {
                    frequencyDist[s.gradeForCryptography].count += 1;
                }
                else
                {
                    frequencyDist.Add(s.gradeForCryptography, new Frequencies(1));
                }

                frequencyDist[s.gradeForCryptography].relativeFreq = Math.Round(frequencyDist[s.gradeForCryptography].count / (studentNumber - 1),2);
                frequencyDist[s.gradeForCryptography].precentage = frequencyDist[s.gradeForCryptography].relativeFreq * 100;
            }

            this.richTextBox1.AppendText("___________________________________" + Environment.NewLine);
            this.richTextBox1.AppendText("Grade ".PadRight(7) + "Frequency " .PadRight(7) + "RFreq ".PadRight(7) + "Percentage ".PadRight(7) + Environment.NewLine);

            foreach (KeyValuePair<int,Frequencies> kvp in frequencyDist)
            {
                this.richTextBox1.AppendText(kvp.Key.ToString().PadRight(7) + " " + kvp.Value.count.ToString().PadRight(7) + " " + kvp.Value.relativeFreq.ToString().PadRight(7) + " " + kvp.Value.precentage.ToString() + " %" + Environment.NewLine);
            }

            decimal intervalSize = 10;
            decimal startingEndPoint = 170;

            //first interval

            Interval myInterval = new Interval();
            myInterval.lowerEnd = startingEndPoint;
            myInterval.upperEnd = startingEndPoint + intervalSize;

            List<Interval> listOfIntervals = new List<Interval>();

            listOfIntervals.Add(myInterval);

            foreach(Student s in listOfStudents)
            {
                Boolean studentInserted = false;

                foreach(Interval i in listOfIntervals)
                {
                    if (s.height > i.lowerEnd && s.height <= i.upperEnd)
                    {
                        i.count += 1;
                        studentInserted = true;
                    }
                }

                if(studentInserted == true)
                {
                    continue;
                }

                if(s.height <= listOfIntervals[0].lowerEnd)
                {
                    while (true)
                    {
                        Interval newLeftInterval = new Interval();
                        newLeftInterval.upperEnd = listOfIntervals[0].lowerEnd;
                        newLeftInterval.lowerEnd = newLeftInterval.upperEnd - intervalSize;

                        listOfIntervals.Insert(0, newLeftInterval);

                        if (s.height > newLeftInterval.lowerEnd && s.height <= newLeftInterval.upperEnd)
                        {
                            newLeftInterval.count += 1;
                            studentInserted = true;
                            break;
                        }

                    }
                }

                else if(s.height > listOfIntervals[listOfIntervals.Count - 1].upperEnd)
                {
                    while (true)
                    {
                        Interval newRightInterval = new Interval();
                        newRightInterval.lowerEnd = listOfIntervals[listOfIntervals.Count - 1].upperEnd;
                        newRightInterval.upperEnd = newRightInterval.lowerEnd + intervalSize;

                        listOfIntervals.Add(newRightInterval);

                        if (s.height > newRightInterval.lowerEnd && s.height <= newRightInterval.upperEnd)
                        {

                            newRightInterval.count += 1;
                            studentInserted = true;
                            break;
                        }

                    }

                }
            }

            this.richTextBox1.AppendText("___________________________________" + Environment.NewLine);
            this.richTextBox1.AppendText("HEIGHT DISTRIBUTION" + Environment.NewLine);
            this.richTextBox1.AppendText("Interval".PadRight(20) + "Count" + Environment.NewLine);

            foreach(Interval i in listOfIntervals)
            {
                this.richTextBox1.AppendText("[ " + i.lowerEnd + " " + i.upperEnd + "] ".PadRight(11) + i.count + Environment.NewLine);
            }
        }

        public class Frequencies
        {
            public decimal count;
            public decimal relativeFreq;
            public decimal precentage;

            public Frequencies(decimal c)
            {
                this.count = c;
            }
            public Frequencies(decimal c, decimal rf, decimal p)
            {
                this.count = c;
                this.relativeFreq = rf;
                this.precentage = p;
            }
        }

        public class Interval
        {
            public decimal lowerEnd, upperEnd, count, relativeFrequency, percentage;

        }
    }
}

            ' OFFLINE ALGO

            Dim sum As Decimal = 0

            Dim average As Decimal = Math.Round(sum / (studentNumber - 1), 2)

            ' ONLINE ALGO

            For Each s As Student In listOfStudents

            Me.richTextBox1.AppendText("___________________________________" & Environment.NewLine)

            Dim frequencyDist As Dictionary(Of Integer, Frequencies) = New Dictionary(Of Integer, Frequencies)()

            For Each s As Student In listOfStudents

                If frequencyDist.ContainsKey(s.gradeForCryptography) Then

                Else
                    frequencyDist.Add(s.gradeForCryptography, New Frequencies(1))
                End If

                frequencyDist(s.gradeForCryptography).relativeFreq = Math.Round(frequencyDist(s.gradeForCryptography).count / (studentNumber - 1), 2)

            Next

            Me.richTextBox1.AppendText("___________________________________" & Environment.NewLine)

            For Each kvp As KeyValuePair(Of Integer, Frequencies) In frequencyDist
                Me.richTextBox1.AppendText(kvp.Key.ToString().PadRight(7) & " " & kvp.Value.count.ToString().PadRight(7) & " " & kvp.Value.relativeFreq.ToString().PadRight(7) & " " & kvp.Value.precentage.ToString() & " %" & Environment.NewLine)
            Next

            Dim intervalSize As Decimal = 10

            listOfIntervals.Add(myInterval)

            For Each s As Student In listOfStudents
                Dim studentInserted As Boolean = False

                For Each i As Interval In listOfIntervals

                    If s.height > i.lowerEnd AndAlso s.height <= i.upperEnd Then
                        i.count += 1

                    End If
                Next

                If studentInserted = True Then
                    Continue For
                End If

                If s.height <= listOfIntervals(0).lowerEnd Then

                    While True
                        Dim newLeftInterval As Interval = New Interval()
                        newLeftInterval.upperEnd = listOfIntervals(0).lowerEnd
                        newLeftInterval.lowerEnd = newLeftInterval.upperEnd - intervalSize
                        listOfIntervals.Insert(0, newLeftInterval)

                        If s.height > newLeftInterval.lowerEnd AndAlso s.height <= newLeftInterval.upperEnd Then
                            newLeftInterval.count += 1
                            studentInserted = True
                            Exit While
                        End If
                    End While
                ElseIf s.height > listOfIntervals(listOfIntervals.Count - 1).upperEnd Then

                    While True
                        Dim newRightInterval As Interval = New Interval()
                        newRightInterval.lowerEnd = listOfIntervals(listOfIntervals.Count - 1).upperEnd
                        newRightInterval.upperEnd = newRightInterval.lowerEnd + intervalSize
                        listOfIntervals.Add(newRightInterval)

                        If s.height > newRightInterval.lowerEnd AndAlso s.height <= newRightInterval.upperEnd Then
                            newRightInterval.count += 1
                            studentInserted = True
                            Exit While
                        End If
                    End While
                End If
            Next

            Me.richTextBox1.AppendText("___________________________________" & Environment.NewLine)
            Me.richTextBox1.AppendText("HEIGHT DISTRIBUTION" & Environment.NewLine)
            Me.richTextBox1.AppendText("Interval".PadRight(20) & "Count" & Environment.NewLine)

            For Each i As Interval In listOfIntervals
                Me.richTextBox1.AppendText("[ " & i.lowerEnd & " " & i.upperEnd & "] ".PadRight(11) & i.count & Environment.NewLine)
            Next
        End Sub

        Public Class Frequencies

            Public Sub New(ByVal c As Decimal, ByVal rf As Decimal, ByVal p As Decimal)

            End Sub
        End Class

    End Class

item.title: 3_R : ONLINE ALGORITHM
item.description: WHAT IS AN ONLINE ALGORITHM? Citing Wikipedia: In computer science, an online algorithm is one that can process its input piece-by-piece in a serial fashion, i.e., in the order that the input is fed to the algorithm, without having the entire input available from the start. In contrast, an offline algorithm is given the whole problem data from the beginning and is required to output an answer which solves the problem at hand.
item.content:
WHAT IS AN ONLINE ALGORITHM?

Citing Wikipedia:

In computer science, an online algorithm is one that can process its input piece-by-piece in a serial fashion, i.e., in the order that the input is fed to the algorithm, without having the entire input available from the start. In contrast, an offline algorithm is given the whole problem data from the beginning and is required to output an answer which solves the problem at hand. (For example, selection sort requires that the entire list be given before it can sort it, while insertion sort doesn’t.)

We can then summarize this definition by saying: an online algorithm takes as input a stream of continuous data, while an offline algorithm attempts to solve the problem by already having all the data available from the first moment.

HOW WE CAN OBTAIN AN ONLINE ALGO FOR THE ARITHMETIC MEAN:

The problem of calculating the average is trivial, most of us since elementary school can solve it, however solving it with an online algorithm is a more complex task. Here, comes in help DONALD KNUTH ,an American computer scientist, mathematician, and professor emeritus at Stanford University, in his book ‚ÄòThe Art of Computer Programming‚Äô wrote an alternative formula to compute the online mean for huge data-stream. The following is the mathematical formula he found to solve the problem:

KAHAN SUMMATION ALGORITHM:

A code version of the algorithm, is the following one introduced by KAHAN, which is designed to minimize errors, this is done by keeping a separate running compensation (a variable that accumulates small errors).

function KahanSum(input)
    var sum = 0.0
    var c = 0.0                 // A running compensation for lost low-order bits.
    for i = 1 to input.length do
        var y = input[i] - c    // So far, so good: c is zero.
        var t = sum + y         // Alas, sum is big, y small, so low-order digits of y are lost.
        c = (t - sum) - y       // (t - sum) cancels the high-order part of y; subtracting y recovers negative (low part of y)
        sum = t                 // Algebraically, c should always be zero. Beware overly-aggressive optimizing compilers!
    next i                      // Next time around, the lost low part will be added to y in a fresh attempt.
    return sum

WHY IS AN ONLINE ALGO BETTER IN THIS CASE?

the answer to the question starts with one word digitalization. We live in an increasingly connected world, where more and more applications are entrusted to computers, so it is unthinkable to be able to store a large amount of data in RAM or hard drive and then use them later, because they take up a lot of space and resources. That’s why we need something more efficient, so over the years the online approach has gained more and more attention, because it allows us to save precious resources. Of course, it’s not all gold that glitters, in fact, for problems that don’t require large amounts of data, an offline approach is preferable because it’s easier to implement and in some cases may even be more efficient.

Credits

  • Federica Sole, Best algorithms to compute the ‚Äúonline data stream‚Äù arithmetic mean

item.content:
What is a Database?

Our discussion of data starts here, the database, but what is actually a database? Citing Oracle:

A database is an organized collection of structured information, or data, typically stored electronically in a computer system. A database is usually controlled by a database management system (DBMS). Together, the data and the DBMS, along with the applications that are associated with them, are referred to as a database system, often shortened to just database.Data within the most common types of databases in operation today is typically modeled in rows and columns in a series of tables to make processing and data querying efficient. The data can then be easily accessed, managed, modified, updated, controlled, and organized. Most databases use structured query language (SQL) for writing and querying data.

so, now that we know what it takes to allow us to record data, we can better address how it is handled in the real world for different purposes.

The Data Warehouse :

First of all, a data warehouse is a particular type of database, but there is a major difference:

  • a database is built to record the data provided to it.
  • a Data Warehouse is designed to perform data aggregations for analytical purposes.

In other words, databases are a mathematical basis for collecting data and querying them for operational purposes. The data warehouse, on the other hand, is an analytical system of data that has strategic purposes in the planning of business processes. In addition, data warehouses are very important in data mining, artificial intelligence (AI), and machine learning.

What is a Data Mart?

We can see the data mart as a focused version of a data warehouse described above. Specifically, citing IBM:

A data mart is a subset of a data warehouse focused on a particular line of business, department, or subject area. Data marts make specific data available to a defined group of users, which allows those users to quickly access critical insights without wasting time searching through an entire data warehouse. For example, many companies may have a data mart that aligns with a specific department in the business, such as finance, sales, or marketing.

Thus, different data marts may exist depending on the areas of study we are interested in.

OLAP and OLTP : two useful tools

We could conceptually summarize what OLAP and OLTP are with a simple question:

  • in the case of OLAP we would ask “what will happen?”
  • in the case of OLTP we would ask “what is happening?”

Definition of OLAP:

OLAP stands for: On-Line Analytical Processsing. We can see it as a set of software techniques that allows to analyze a large amount of collected data and it is the basic technology of data warehouse. Companies use it to predict sales results, cost trends, results of marketing and communication campaigns, organize survey data and other similar cases. We can therefore summarize everything in the fact that the OLAP analysis system is one of the tools that can allow you to make business decisions.

Definition of OLTP:

OLTP stands for: On-Line Transaction Processsing. we can see it as a set of software techniques that are used to manage transaction-oriented applications. It is popular in financial transactions, retail sales, and customer relationship management (CRM). Booking airline tickets online, online banking, online shopping are practical examples of systems based on the use of OLTP. OLTP is used to record insertion, update and deletion of data during a transaction. So, as you can imagine these operations in order to ensure reliability must be atomic. Also, OLTP queries are simpler and shorter and thus require less time in processing and less storage space. A key aspect is:

we can see OLTP as the data source for OLAP.

OLAP vs OLTP:

OLAP tools differ from OLTPs in that the former aim to find and achieve queries that are as complex as possible; the latter, on the other hand, aim to ensure integrity and security of transactions.

Below is a list of other substantial differences between the two:

  • OLTP is an online transaction system instead OLAP is an online data retrieval and analysis system; online transaction data is the data source for OLTP;
  • OLTP’s main operations are inserting, updating and deleting data while OLAP’s main operation is extracting complex data for later analysis;
  • OLAP has a long and less frequent transaction while OLTP has short but frequent transactions; OLTP’s response times are much faster than OLAP as it deals with short transactions.
  • OLAP queries are very complex compared to OLTP, as they deal with a much larger amount of data and are also more structured.
  • OLAP databases are not changed frequently, so data integrity is not affected. OLTP databases, on the other hand, are changed frequently, so it is important to maintain data integrity.
  • OLAP is used for planning and decision making while OLTP is used for controlling and executing key business activities.
